to the inn,<del loc="novel1_letter4_chapter22_del648__End"/>leaving the shore we sought the retreat of our house and garden. <del loc="novel1_letter4_chapter22_del648__Start"/>but<del loc="novel1_letter4_chapter22_del648__End"/><del loc="novel1_letter4_chapter22_del648__Start"/>a<del loc="novel1_letter4_chapter22_del648__End"/>Again as I entered the iron gates of the demesne, an <del loc="novel1_letter4_chapter22_del648__Start"/>unres<del loc="novel1_letter4_chapter22_del648__End"/> unexplainable feeling bade me hold—yet Elizabeth unwarned, and fearless passed on, and I, again half ashamed—& for the first time dreading lest any unholy sight should meet her sense, any shadow of the fiend, should cross her, <del loc="novel1_letter4_chapter22_del648__Start"/>I<del loc="novel1_letter4_chapter22_del648__End"/> hastily walked on, and passing my arm round her prayed with a feeling of bitter tenderness, that she might never suffer ill. Thus we entered the <del loc="novel1_letter4_chapter22_del648__Start"/>ar<del loc="novel1_letter4_chapter22_del648__End"/> mansion—and still not speaking, for both our hearts were too full, we went
